Award.AwardTitle: The Mass of the First Stars and Black Holes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support a postdoctoral scholar and graduate student?s efforts to develop radiation hydrodynamical simulations of HII region breakouts of primordial protostars. These models will also include the effects of protostellar rotation, WIMP annihilation heating, and disk photo-evaporation, and are needed in order to better understand how the first stars (Population III.1) formed.

This work has broader impacts in that some research results will be integrated into teaching and public outreach activities of the PI. An upper mass limit of the first stars will be an important input for models of early universe chemical evolution as well as galaxy and globular cluster formation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to understand how the first stars and black holes formed in the Universe - that is, the very foundations of the formation and evolution of the populations of galaxies that we see around us today. Our research was in two main areas. First we developed models for how the very first stars, which would have been lacking most elements heavier than Helium, formed. The internal structure of the forming stars, i.e., "protostars",  was calculated, which allows prediction of their surface temperatures and thus their output of energetic photons than can ionize the surrounding collapsing gas from which they are forming. This "feedback" of the star on the gas is thought to be crucial in limiting the masses of the stars. We presented caclulations that indicate that under fiducial conditions, the masses of these stars are expected to be about 50 times the mass of the Sun. This is actually significantly smaller mass than previous calculations have suggested, with implications for the kinds of supernova explosions that would result and thus the amount of heavy elements that would be released after the stars die. Future directions of this work include exploring how such feedback processes operate over a range of conditions in the Universe to the present day.

Second, we explored a new scenario of star formation in the early universe, which may occur when the star is accreting gas near the center of a dark matter halo. This may only occur for the very earliest objects. While the nature of dark matter remains mysterious, many classes of models involve a weakly interacting massive particle (WIMP), which can self-annihilate to release energy. This energy changes the structure of the protostar, causing it to be much larger and with a cooler surface temperature. Such a temperature means that the star has much lower levels of ionizing feedback, which then can enable the star to accrete a lot more mass, potentially reaching about 100,000 solar masses. We carried out calculations of the growth and formation of such "supermassive" stars. These stars are likely to then eventually end their lives forming supermassive black holes (SMBHs). SMBHs are seen today in the centers of most large galaxies, including the Milky Way. They are the power source of "Active Galactic Nuclei" (AGN), including Quasars. However, although there are many different theories for how they form, there is no consensus at the moment. We have investigated the new scenario of WIMP annihilation heating supporting supermassive star formation as the mechanism that could form all the SMBHs. We carried out cosmological volume simulations that predicted the time and place of SMBH formation by this mechanism. The results of these calculations are very promising as they naturally predict the observed number density of SMBHs that we see in the Universe today.

During the course of this research, two Ph.D. students have been partially supported by this grant, contributing to their education and training. A postdoctoral researcher also worked on the project. Appropriate research results were integrated into the educational and outreach activities of the principle investigator, the postdoc and students.
